title: How to correct this: “He is my oldest son.”, “This boy is older than I” and “Two and two makes four” - Quora

response.answer_text: How can I correct this: “He is my oldest son.”, “This boy is older than I” and “Two and two makes four”? Here are my observations: “He is my oldest son.” (This is perfectly okay in North America, but in other countries, you’ll want to change this to “He is my eldest son.”)“This boy is older than I” (No. This is no longer considered natural English. Better to say either “This boy is older than I am” or “This boy is older than me”.“Two and two makes four” (Perfectly fine in speech and in informal writing, but it’s a little to colloquial for formal writing. In formal writing, say “Two plus two equals four.”

First sentence. I would prefer to say, “He is my eldest son.” Second sentence. I would say, “This boy is older than I am.” Where I live most people say, ,”Older than me.” Third sentence. I prefer. “Two and two equals four. When I was at school (60 years ago) we recited the tables and said, two and two makes four but I was always left wondering, four what.
